bestBHT.bht: A crowd of worthless market people, moved by envy and stirred up by Jewish preachers, burst into the house where Paul and Silas were staying. Fuelled by a blind and ignorant zeal for religious customs and traditions, they intended to subject Paul and Silas to popular fury. Their wicked zeal, masked by the name of God, was tainted with hypocrisy and poisoned malice. This disturbance caused by idle loungers violated the laws of the Roman emperor and brought great turmoil to the city.

Henry Alford: of the baser sort] Literally, of men out of the markets, or loungers in the forum: such persons as are every where known to be the scum of the population.
These may be alluded to in 1 Thess. ii. 14.
Jason] With whom (ver. 7) Paul and Silas lodged.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: the Jews . . . moved with envy—seeing their influence undermined by this stranger.
lewd fellows of the baser sort—better, perhaps, 'worthless market people,' that is, idle loungers about the market-place, of indifferent character.
assaulted the house of Jason—with whom Paul and Silas abode, one of Paul's kinsmen, apparently, and from his name, probably a Hellenistic Jew.
Albert Barnes: Certain lewd fellows of the baser sort - This is an unhappy translation.
The pretence on which the mob was excited was, that they had everywhere produced disturbance, and that they violated the laws of the Roman emperor.

The profane, the worthless, and the abandoned thus often become violently enraged for the honor of religion, and full of indignation and tumult against those who are accused of violating public peace and order.
Marvin Vincent: The word occurs only here and ch. 19 38, on which see note."
Of the baser sort [αγοραιων] . From ajgora, the market - place; hence loungers in the market - place; the rabble.
Gathered a company [οχλοποιησαντες] . Rev., better, a crowd.. Only here in New Testament.
John Calvin: Therefore, all the servants of Christ must be content with this one example of him, if they see that their labor doth yield some fruit, they must recompense all manner of persecutions with this reward.

And though they do always pretend the name of God for an excuse of their disordered zeal, yet this history doth plainly declare, that mere hypocrisy doth reign inwardly, and that all corners of their hearts are stuffed with poisoned malice.

Therefore, let us know that wicked zeal, which is hot [boils] in superstitious men, is always infected with hypocrisy and malice; and this is the cause that it breaketh out into cruelty without keeping any measure.
Philip Schaff: The modern word equivalent would be 'canaille.' The loungers who have no definite business, who crowd the market-place and other busy resorts, ready for any piece of business however rough and cruel, are the class here spoken of.
It has been suggested with some probability that this Jason was an Hellenistic Jew, whose name Jesus or Joshua had been changed into the Greek form 'Jason'... He was possibly a relative of Paul's.
The apostle and Silas very likely lodged in the house of Jason during their stay at Thessalonica.
Archibald T. Robertson: The success of Paul was entirely too great in both places to please the rabbis. So here is jealousy of Jewish preachers towards Christian preachers.
The αγορα or market-place was the natural resort for those with nothing to do like the court-house square today or various parks in our cities where bench-warmers flock.
They burst into the house and searched up and down. They were getting ready to have a lynching party.
John Gill: it was a blind and ignorant zeal, a zeal for the rites and ceremonies of the law of Moses, and for the traditions of the elders.
they raised a mob, and made a clamour, which brought people out of their houses to inquire what was the matter, and so gave great disturbance and uneasiness to the inhabitants.
their intention was to have dragged them out and exposed them to popular fury, to be beaten or stoned by the people.

bhtAttempts.bht: A crowd of worthless market people, fueled by envy and stirred up by Jewish preachers, assaulted the house where Paul and Silas were staying. They burst into the house with the intention of causing harm, searching up and down and preparing for a potential lynching party. These idle loungers were easily roused by the pretense of disturbance, violating the laws of the Roman emperor. It is clear that their wicked zeal, masked by the name of God, was driven by hypocrisy and poisoned malice. This blind and ignorant zeal for religious customs and traditions caused them to incite a mob and bring great disturbance to the city, intending to subject Paul and Silas to popular fury.

This disturbance caused by idle loungers violated the laws of the Roman emperor and brought turmoil to the city.
